title: 114_s3191
content:
The "Rural Health Care Quality Improvement Act of 2016" establishes a core set of rural health care quality measures and makes revisions to Medicare rural grants. It also includes rural-based payment reforms. Title III of the "Rural Health Care Quality Improvement Act of 2016" focuses on improving rural representation through various initiatives such as integrating quality measures into payment models, testing financial incentives for rural providers to submit data, and implementing value-based payment models for rural providers. Additionally, there are programs to reduce hospital readmissions for rural hospitals and allow rural health clinics to participate in the Comprehensive Primary Care Plus model. Title I of the "Rural Health Care Quality Improvement Act of 2016" establishes a core set of rural health care quality measures under Title XVIII of the Social Security Act. This includes provisions for rural representation on various healthcare councils and commissions. The "Rural Health Care Quality Improvement Act of 2016" establishes a core set of quality measures for rural providers to improve patient outcomes, care coordination, cost reduction, patient safety, preventive care, chronic disease management, and other purposes specified by the Secretary. The Secretary will establish a core set of quality measures for small rural providers to reduce reporting burdens. These measures will align with other quality reporting requirements and will be updated annually to ensure reliability. The Secretary will establish quality measures for small rural providers to reduce reporting burdens, ensuring reliability and alignment with other requirements. Section 1890A will maintain the reliability, validity, and appropriateness of quality measures, while a conforming amendment includes rural health care quality measures under section 1890B. SEC. 102. REVISIONS TO MEDICARE RURAL GRANTS. Revisions to Medicare rural grants include amendments to the Social Security Act for appropriations to the HI trust fund and grants for emergency medical services in rural communities. Additionally, there are grants for technical assistance in quality improvement reporting by critical access hospitals. The Social Security Act is amended to provide grants for technical assistance in quality improvement reporting by critical access hospitals. These grants aim to support the establishment or expansion of quality improvement reporting programs and provide technical assistance to eligible hospitals. Critical access hospitals must submit an application to the Secretary to be considered for these grants. Additionally, there is a reporting requirement for hospitals to continue receiving grants after the second year. The Secretary may award grants to critical access hospitals for up to 2 years, contingent on the submission of relevant quality data specified by the Secretary. Procedures will be established for making the data available to the public, and hospitals will have the opportunity to review the data before it is made public. The Secretary will report quality measures of process, structure, outcome, and patients. The Secretary will report quality measures related to process, structure, outcome, patients' perspective on care, efficiency, and costs of care for hospitals on the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services website. TITLE II--RURAL-BASED PAYMENT REFORMS

SEC. 201. INTEGRATING RURAL HEALTH CARE QUALITY MEASURES INTO PAYMENT MODELS:
Amends the Social Security Act to include rural health care quality measures in alternative payment models and value-based payment projects starting in 2021.

SEC. 202. CENTER FOR MEDICARE AND MEDICAID INNOVATION TESTING FINANCIAL INCENTIVES FOR RURAL PROVIDERS:
Establishes testing for financial incentives for rural providers to submit data on quality measures. Section 1115A of the Social Security Act is amended to include a model providing financial incentives for rural providers to submit data on quality measures. Additionally, a new section is added for testing value-based payment models for rural providers of services and suppliers under the Center for Medicare and Medicaid Innovation. Section 1115A of the Social Security Act is amended to include value-based payment models for rural providers of services and suppliers, including critical access hospitals. Additionally, a new section is added for testing a Hospital Readmissions Reduction Program for rural hospitals under the Center for Medicare and Medicaid Innovation. Section 1115A of the Social Security Act is amended to include a Hospital Readmissions Reduction Program for rural hospitals. Additionally, rural health clinics and Federally qualified health centers are permitted to participate in the Comprehensive Primary Care Plus model. TITLE III--IMPROVING RURAL REPRESENTATION

SEC. 301. INCLUSION OF RURAL REPRESENTATION ON CMS RURAL HEALTH COUNCIL.

The Administrator of CMS must include external stakeholders with rural health expertise on the Rural Health Council, collaborating with the Health Care Payment Learning and Action Network.

SEC. 302. ENSURING RURAL REPRESENTATION ON MEDICARE PAYMENT ADVISORY COMMISSION AND MEDICAID AND CHIP PAYMENT AND ACCESS COMMISSION. In order to improve rural representation, amendments are made to include at least two members representing rural areas in the Medicare Payment Advisory Commission and the Medicaid and CHIP Payment and Access Commission. These changes apply to future appointments made by the Comptroller General of the United States. Future appointments made by the Comptroller General of the United States must comply with the requirements of the Social Security Act.
